intro: Nepeta agrestis, commonly known as field catmint, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and produces clusters of small, blue to purple flowers. Its leaves are opposite, ovate to lanceolate, and emit a strong mint-like fragrance when crushed. Nepeta agrestis is often found in meadows, woodland edges, and disturbed soils, thriving in full sun to partial shade.
